Devosia crocina is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Devosia, which is part of the family Devosiaceae within the phylum Proteobacteria. It is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, aerobic, and rod-shaped bacterium.

The distinctive feature of Devosia crocina is its ability to produce a characteristic orange-yellow pigment, which is likely due to the presence of carotenoid compounds. This pigmentation is the basis for the species name "crocina," which is derived from the Latin word "crocinus," meaning "saffron-yellow."

Devosia crocina was first isolated from soil samples collected in South Korea. It is known to be able to thrive in various environmental conditions, including the ability to tolerate a range of temperatures and pH levels.

The genome of Devosia crocina has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential ecological roles. Further research on this species may contribute to our understanding of bacterial diversity and their adaptations to different habitats.
